   94.25   Burning of leaves



 



   94.99   Penalty



Cross-reference:



   Excessive noise from operation of motor vehicle, see Ch. 75



NOISE



§ 94.01  CONSTRUCTION NOISE.



   (A)   Times.  The noise emanating from construction or maintenance
activities occurring within residential zoned districts of the village
including but not limited to noises such as hammering, sawing, drilling,
excavating, heavy construction vehicles and equipment operation, pumping, and
sandblasting is prohibited except when the noise occurs between the hours of
7:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. Monday through Friday, and 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m.
Saturdays and Sundays; and the noise does not cause a public nuisance.



   (B)   Exemptions.  Noise emanating from village, county or state
authorized emergency, repair or maintenance projects occurring within
residential zoned districts are exempt from this provision.



(Ord. 1463, passed 6-20-94)  Penalty, see § 94.99



Cross-references:



   Dog packs as nuisances, see § 92.06



   For circumstances under which dogs are considered nuisances, see §
92.20



WEEDS



§ 94.10  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   DEBRIS.  Scattered remains: ruins; discarded waste: litter.



   GARBAGE.  The animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking and consumption of food.



   REFUSE.  Something rejected or discarded as worthless: trash.



   RUBBISH.  Combustible and noncombustible waste materials, except
garbage; the term shall include the residue from the burning of wood, coal,
coke, and other combustible materials; paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood,
excelsior, rubber, leather, tree branches, yard trimmings, tin cans, metals,
mineral matter, glass, crockery and dust and other similar materials.



   TRASH.  Worthless, discarded material; junk.



   WEEDS.  Includes, but is not limited to, thistles, cockleburrs, Canada
thistles and all of its varieties, perennial sow thistles, European Bentwood,
Leafy Spurge, Russian Knapwood, Johnson Grass, Giant Foxtail, Hoary Cress,
Jimson, Burdock, Cockleburrs, Ragweed and similar weeds and all weeds which,
due to pollution are a menace to health, are, for purposes of this section,
deemed noxious weeds.



(Ord. 1103, passed 1-3-84; Am. Ord. 1581, passed 6-17-96)



§ 94.11  WEEDS AND LITTER ON PROPERTY.



   All record fee title owners, beneficiaries of any trust holding title
to any real estate, individual(s), partnership, firm, or corporation owning,
occupying, or in any way in possession of any property within the corporate
limits of the village shall fully comply with each of the following
requirements.



   (A)   All grasses used for landscaping purposes, excluding
ornamental grasses, shall not exceed six inches in height at any time of the
year and/or in any season of the year. All grasses grown wild on vacant
property shall not exceed eight inches in height at any time of the year
and/or in any season of the year.



   (B)   No person owning, leasing, occupying or controlling any plot
of real estate shall permit the growth of noxious weeds thereon.  All weeds
shall be pulled or otherwise destroyed by the owner, lessee, tenant, occupant
or person in control of real estate in the village.  Failure to destroy such
weeds within the designated period shall constitute a violation of this
section.



   (C)   Promptly remove and eliminate any debris, refuse, garbage,
rubbish, trash, materials new or discarded and deposits of deposed articles
or material.  Promptly remove all dead grass, dry leaves or similar
dangerous flammable material on the property.



   (D)   Promptly remove and eliminate any weeds or vegetation
specifically barred or in any other way prohibited by state statute or
regulation, including, but not limited to, marijuana.



(Ord. 1103, passed 1-3-84; Am. Ord. 1581, passed 6-17-96; Am. Ord. 2415,
passed 9-17-07)  Penalty, see § 94.99



§ 94.12  CERTAIN WEEDS DECLARED A NUISANCE.



   (A)   All weeds and vegetation which are not cut, removed, or
eliminated (as required herein) or all dead grass, dry weeds, or other
flammable material remaining on such property or debris, refuse, or deposits
of disposed or discarded materials which are subject to this subchapter are
deemed a public nuisance to the village.



   (B)   In addition to any other remedies provided herein, the village
may institute proceedings to abate such nuisances by appropriate judicial
proceedings.



(Ord. 1103, passed 1-3-84)  Penalty, see § 94.99



§ 94.13  ABATEMENT PROCEDURE.



   (A)   In addition to the penalty provision provided, in the event of
the refusal or neglect by the owner or owners and/or occupiers of the
property to cut, destroy and/or remove weeds and combustible material or
otherwise comply with the terms of § 94.11, the village at its sole option
and election, may enter upon said premises and correct the violations of this
subchapter at the expense of the owner or owners of the premises, with all
costs and charges associated with such work being the debt and obligation of
and payable to the village by such owner or owners and/or occupiers of said
premises.  The cost and expense incurred by the village, or by the person or
firm performing the service by authority of the village, in the removal or
cutting down of such weeds or grasses, removal and elimination of any debris,
refuse or deposits of disposed articles or material on such real property
including reasonable attorney's fees, shall constitute a lien upon the real
estate affected, and a lien shall be enforced as provided by statute.



   (B)   Any lien permitted by this subchapter may be enforced by
obtaining a judgment against the owner or owners and/or occupiers of said
property for such charges and costs of suit, or by filing a claim for lien
therefor in the County Recorder’s Office, giving the description of the
property, itemizing the charges and giving the date thereof, said claim for
lien to be supported by affidavit, and which said claim for lien may be
foreclosed in the manner provided by law for foreclosure of other statutory
liens.



   (C)   All remedies provided herein are deemed cumulative so that the
use or implementation of one remedy does not bar or preclude the use of any
other available remedy for such violators.



(Ord. 1103, passed 1-3-84; Am. Ord. 1581, passed 6-17-96)



§ 94.14  NOTICE OF VIOLATION.



   The Director of Code Enforcement or such other authorized village
official, or representative thereof, shall serve or cause to be served an
annual notice representing that it will be the only correspondence from the
village regarding this subchapter, and in the event of violation the village
will remedy the condition according to the terms of this subchapter upon any
person owning, leasing, occupying or controlling any vacant, unimproved real
estate in the village. Said notice shall contain language requiring such
person to remove or cut down the weeds, remove and eliminate any debris,
refuse, garbage, rubbish, trash or deposits of disposed articles or material
constituting such nuisance within seven days from the date of the notice, or
said notice may be given by any one of the four following described methods:



   (A)   By a written notice sent by United States regular and/or
certified mail, postage prepaid, to the last known person owning, leasing,
occupying or controlling the real estate, and as to the owner, the notice may
be addressed to the address shown on the most recent tax bill for the real
estate; or



   (B)   By a written notice personally delivered by the Director or
such other authorized village representative to the person owning, leasing,
occupying, or controlling the real estate; or



   (C)   By posting or tagging a written notice on the property of the
person owning, leasing, occupying, or controlling the real estate upon which
the violation exists. Said notice shall state the date of the posting or
tagging and shall provide that said weeds shall be destroyed not later than
seven days after the notice has been posted or tagged on said property.



   (D)   At the election of the village the person owning, leasing,
occupying or controlling any real estate in the village may be notified by
the village by regular or certified mail of the village's intent to serve an
annual notice. This notice shall contain the necessary language to conform
with this subchapter and also contain the language notifying the owner,
lessee, tenant, occupant or person in control of real estate in the village
that this will be the only correspondence from the village regarding this
subchapter and in the event of violation the village will remedy the
condition according to the terms of this subchapter.



(Ord. 1103, passed 1-3-84; Am. Ord. 1581, passed 6-17-96)



§ 94.15  LIEN FOR REMOVAL COSTS.



   (A)   If the village incurs a removal cost under §§ 94.10, 94.11,
94.12, 94.13, or 94.14 with respect to any underlying parcel, then that cost
is a lien upon that underlying parcel. This lien is superior to all other
liens and encumbrances, except tax liens and as otherwise provided in
division (C) below.



   (B)   (1)   To perfect a lien under this section, the village
must, within one year after the removal cost is incurred, file notice of lien
in the office of the Recorder in the county in which the underlying parcel is
located or, if the underlying parcel is registered under the Torrens system,
in the office of the Registrar of Titles of that county. The notice must
consist of a sworn statement setting out:



         (a)   A description of the underlying parcel that
sufficiently identifies the parcel;



         (b)   The amount of the removal cost; and



         (c)   The date or dates when the removal cost was
incurred by the village.



      (2)   If, for any one parcel, the village engaged in any
removal activity on more than one occasion during the course of one year,
then the village may combine any or all of the costs of each of those
activities into a single notice of lien.



   (C)   A lien under this section is not valid as to:



      (1)   Any purchaser whose rights in and to the underlying
parcel arose after the removal activity but before the filing of the notice
of lien; or



      (2)   Any mortgagee, judgment creditor, or other lienor whose
rights in and to the underlying parcel arose before the filing of the notice
of lien.



   (D)   The removal cost is not a lien on the underlying parcel unless
a notice is personally served on, or sent by certified mail to, the person to
whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the
taxable year immediately preceding the removal activities. The notice must be
delivered or sent after the removal activities have been performed, and it
must:



      (1)   State the substance of this section and the substance of
any ordinance of the village implementing this section;



      (2)   Identify the underlying parcel, by common description;
and



      (3)   Describe the removal activity.



   (E)   A lien under this section may be enforced by proceedings to
foreclose as in case of mortgages or mechanics liens. An action to foreclose
a lien under this section must be commenced within two years after the date
of filing notice of lien.



   (F)   Any person who performs a removal activity by the authority of
the village may, in his or her own name, file a lien and foreclose on that
lien in the same manner as the village under this section.



   (G)   A failure to file a foreclosure action does not, in any way,
affect the validity of the lien against the underlying parcel.



   (H)   Upon payment of the lien cost by the owner of the underlying
parcel after notice of lien has been filed, the village (or its agent under
division (F)) shall release the lien, and the release may be filed of record
by the owner at his or her sole expense as in the case of filing notice of
lien.



   (I)   For the purposes of this section, the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning.



      LIEN COST.  The removal cost and the filing costs for any notice
of lien under division (B).



      REMOVAL ACTIVITY.  Any activity for which a removal cost was
incurred.



      REMOVAL COST.  A removal cost as defined under § 94.13.



      UNDERLYING PARCEL. A parcel of private property upon which a
removal activity was performed.



      YEAR.  A 365-day period.



   (J)   This section applies only to liens filed after August 14, 2009
(the effective date of Public Act 96-462).



   (K)   This section shall not apply to a lien filed pursuant to §
94.16.



(Ord. 2718, passed 5-16-11)



§ 94.16  LIEN FOR COSTS OF REMOVAL, SECURING AND ENCLOSING ON ABANDONED
RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY.



   (A)   If the village elects to incur a removal cost pursuant to §§
94.10, 94.11, 94.12, 94.13, or 94.14 with respect to an abandoned residential
property, then that cost is a lien upon the underlying parcel of that
abandoned residential property. This lien is superior to all other liens and
encumbrances, except tax liens and as otherwise provided in this section.



   (B)   (1)   To perfect a lien under this section, the village
must, within one year after the cost is incurred for the activity, file
notice of the lien in the office of the Recorder in the county in which the
abandoned residential property is located or, if the abandoned residential
property is registered under the Torrens system, in the office of the
Registrar of Titles of that county, a sworn statement setting out:



         (a)   A description of the abandoned residential
property that sufficiently identifies the parcel;



         (b)   The amount of the cost of the activity;



         (c)   The date or dates when the cost for the activity
was incurred by the municipality; and



         (d)   A statement that the lien has been filed pursuant
to §§ 94.10, 94.11, 94.12, 94.13, or 94.14, as applicable.



      (2)   If, for any abandoned residential property, the village
engaged in any activity on more than one occasion during the course of one
year, then the village may combine any or all of the costs of each of those
activities into a single notice of lien.



   (C)   To enforce a lien pursuant to this section, the village must
maintain contemporaneous records that include, at a minimum:



      (1)   A dated statement of finding by the village that the
property for which the work is to be performed has become abandoned
residential property, which shall include:



         (a)   The date when the property was first known or
observed to be unoccupied by any lawful occupant or occupants;



         (b)   A description of the actions taken by the village
to contact the legal owner or owners of the property identified on the
recorded mortgage, or, if known, any agent of the owner or owners, including
the dates such actions were taken; and



         (c)   A statement that no contacts were made with the
legal owner or owners or their agents as a result of such actions;



      (2)   A dated certification by an authorized official of the
village of the necessity and specific nature of the work to be performed;



      (3)   A copy of the agreement with the person or entity
performing the work that includes the legal name of the person or entity, the
rate or rates to be charged for performing the work, and an estimate of the
total cost of the work to be performed;



      (4)   Detailed invoices and payment vouchers for all payments
made by the village for such work; and



      (5)   A statement as to whether the work was engaged through a
competitive bidding process, and if so, a copy of all proposals submitted by
the bidders for such work.



   (D)   A lien under this section shall be enforceable exclusively at
the hearing for confirmation of sale of the abandoned residential property
that is held pursuant to ILCS Ch. 735, Act 5, § 15-1508(b) and shall be
limited to a claim of interest in the proceeds of the sale and subject to the
requirements of this section. Any mortgagee who holds a mortgage on the
property, or any beneficiary or trustee who holds a deed of trust on the
property, may contest the lien or the amount of the lien at any time during
the foreclosure proceeding upon motion and notice in accordance with court
rules applicable to motions generally. Grounds for forfeiture of the lien or
the superior status of the lien granted by division (A) above shall include,
but not be limited to, a finding by the court that:



      (1)   The village has not complied with divisions (B) and (C)
above;



      (2)   The scope of the work was not reasonable under the
circumstances;



      (3)   The work exceeded the authorization for the work to be
performed under §§ 94.10, 94.11, 94.12, 94.13, or 94.14, as applicable; or



      (4)   The cost of the services rendered or materials provided
was not commercially reasonable. Forfeiture of the superior status of the
lien otherwise granted by this section shall, not constitute a forfeiture of
the lien as a subordinate lien.



   (E)   Upon payment of the amount of a lien filed under this section
by the mortgagee, servicer, owner, or any other person, the village shall
release the lien, and the release may be filed of record by the person making
such payment at the person's sole expense as in the case of filing notice of
lien.



   (F)   Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the
village may not file a lien pursuant to this section for activities performed
pursuant to §§ 94.10, 94.11, 94.12, 94.13, or 94.14, if:



      (1)   The mortgagee or servicer of the abandoned residential
property has provided notice to the village that the mortgagee or servicer
has performed or will perform the remedial actions specified in the notice
that the village otherwise might perform pursuant to §§ 94.10, 94.11,
94.12, 94.13, or 94.14 provided that the remedial actions specified in the
notice have been performed or are performed or initiated in good faith within
30 days of such notice; or



      (2)   The village has provided notice to the mortgagee or
servicer of a problem with the property requiring the remedial actions
specified in the notice that the village otherwise would perform pursuant to
§§ 94.10, 94.11, 94.12, 94.13, or 94.14, and the mortgagee or servicer has
performed or performs or initiates in good faith the remedial actions
specified in the notice within 30 days of such notice.



   (G)   This section shall apply only to activities performed, costs
incurred, and liens filed after the effective date of this amendatory Act of
the 96th General Assembly.



   (H)   For the purposes of this section the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning.



      ABANDONED RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY. Any type of permanent residential
dwelling unit, including detached single family structures, and townhouses,
condominium units and multifamily rental apartments covering the entire
property, and manufactured homes treated under Illinois law as real estate
and not as personal property, that has been unoccupied by any lawful occupant
or occupants for at least 90 days, and for which after such 90-day period,
the village has made good faith efforts to contact the legal owner or owners
of the property identified on the recorded mortgage, or, if known, any agent
of the owner or owners, and no contact has been made. A property for which
the village has been given notice of the order of confirmation of sale
pursuant to ILCS Ch. 735, Act 5, § 15-1508(b-10) shall not be deemed to be
an abandoned residential property for the purposes of this section.



      MERS PROGRAM. The nationwide Mortgage Electronic Registration
System approved by Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac, and Ginnie Mae that has been
created by the mortgage banking industry with the mission of registering
every mortgage loan in the United States to lawfully make information
concerning each residential mortgage loan and the property securing it
available by Internet access to mortgage originators, servicers, warehouse
lenders, wholesale lenders, retail lenders, document custodians, settlement
agents, title companies, insurers, investors, county recorders, units of
local government, and consumers.



   (I)   Any entity or person who performs a removal, securing, or
enclosing activity pursuant to the authority of a village under this section
may, in its, his, or her own name, file a lien pursuant to division (B) above
and appear in a foreclosure action on that lien pursuant to division (D) of
this section in the place of the village, provided that the village shall
remain subject to division (C) above, and. such party shall be subject to all
of the provisions in this section as if such party were the village.



   (J)   All amounts received by the village for costs incurred
pursuant to this section for which the village has been reimbursed under
Section 7.31 of the Illinois Housing Development Act shall be remitted to the
State Treasurer for deposit into the Abandoned Residential Property
Municipality Relief Fund.



(Ord. 2718, passed 5-16-11)



OPEN BURNING



§ 94.25  BURNING OF LEAVES.



   (A)   The burning of leaves and grass clippings shall be prohibited
in the village, except as otherwise provided from time to time by village
resolution restricting the burning of the aforementioned items to specified
weekends during spring and fall.



   (B)   The Fire Protection District, the Police Department and the
Building Department shall have the right to go upon any private property to
enforce the provisions of this section and to extinguish any leaves that are
burning in violation of this section.



(Ord. 1536, passed 10-2-95; Am. Ord. 1815, passed 7-17-00)



Cross-reference:



   Open burning on public streets and ways, see § 96.01



§ 94.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   In addition to all other remedies to the village at law or
equity, any person or entity who violates or fails to comply with §§ 94.01,
94.11 and 94.12 shall be fined not less than $50 or not more than $750 for
each offense.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.



   (B)   In addition to the penalties provided above, if any person
notified fails or refuses to comply with the notice, the village may cause
weeds to be removed or cut down, remove and eliminate any debris, refuse,
garbage, rubbish, trash or deposits of disposed articles or material in any
manner it designates and shall charge the costs of such removal to the person
owning, leasing, occupying or controlling the real estate.  The cost for
such cutting or removal shall be calculated on the basis of $10 per 1,000
square feet of real estate or fraction thereof or actual costs of services
whichever is greater, for the first offense, and $20 per 1,000 square feet of
real estate or actual costs of services whichever is greater, for all
subsequent offenses.  The cost and expense incurred by the village, or by
the person or firm performing the service by authority of the village, in the
removal or cutting following the refusal or failure of the responsible party
to remove or cut down such weeds, remove and eliminate any debris, refuse,
garbage, rubbish or deposits of disposed articles or material, and including
reasonable attorney's fees, shall constitute a lien upon the real estate
affected, and a lien shall be enforced as provided by statute.



(Ord. 1581, passed 6-17-96)



   (C)   In addition to all other remedies to the village at law or
equity, any person who violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions
of § 94.25 shall be fined not less than $50 or not more than $750 for each
offense.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.  (Ord. 1536, passed
10-2-95)



(Am. Ord. 1943, passed 12-2-02)

PARADES



§ 95.01  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



      PARADE.  Any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant,
or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street,
park, or other public place in the village.



(Ord. 661, passed 6-1-70)



§ 95.02  COMPLIANCE.



   A permittee hereunder shall comply with all permit directions and
conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances.



(Ord. 661, passed 6-1-70)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.03  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form, or start any
parade, unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the Chief of
Police with the following exceptions.



   (A)   Funeral processions;



   (B)   Any educational function under the direction and supervision
of the proper school authorities;



   (C)   A governmental agency acting within the scope of its authority.



(Ord. 661, passed 6-1-70)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.04  APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.



   A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application
with the Chief of Police on forms provided by such officer.



   (A)   Filing period.  An application for a parade permit shall be
filed with the Chief of Police not less than 48 hours nor more than 60 days
before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade.



   (B)   Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth
the following information.



      (1)   The name, address, and telephone number of the person
seeking to conduct such parade;



      (2)   If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf
of, or by an organization, the name, address, and telephone number of the
headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads
of such organization;



      (3)   The name, address, and telephone number of the person
who will be the Parade Chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct;



      (4)   The date when the parade is to be conducted;



      (5)   The route to be traveled, the starting point, and the
termination point;



      (6)   The approximate number of persons who, and animals and
vehicles which, will constitute such parade; the type of animals, and
description of the vehicles;



      (7)   The hours when such parade will start and terminate;



      (8)   A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or
only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed;



      (9)   The location by streets of any assembly areas for such
parade;



      (10)   The time at which units of the parade will begin to
assemble at any such assembly area or areas;



      (11)   If the parade is designed to be held by, and on behalf
of or for, any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit
shall file with the Chief of Police a communication in writing from the
person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for
the permit on his behalf; and



      (12)   Any additional information which the Chief of Police
shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a
permit should be issued.



   (C)   Late applications. The Chief of Police, where good cause is
shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application
hereunder which is filed less than 48 hours before the date such parade is
proposed to be conducted.



(Ord. 661, passed 6-1-70)



§ 95.05  CONDITIONS FOR ISSUANCE OF PERMIT.



   (A)   The Chief of Police shall issue a permit as provided for
hereunder when, from a consideration of the application and from such other
information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds the following.



      (1)   The conduct of the parade will not substantially
interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its
route;



      (2)   The concentration of persons, animals, and vehicles at
assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and
police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such
assembly areas;



      (3)   The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the
movement of fire-fighting equipment en route to a fire;



      (4)   The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of
advertising any product, goods, or event, and is not designed to be held
purely for private profit.



   (B)   Upon issuance of a parade permit, the Chief of Police shall
send a copy thereof or otherwise notify the Village President.



(Ord. 661, passed 6-1-70)



§ 95.06  DENIAL OF PERMIT; APPEAL.



   (A)   The Chief of Police shall act upon the application for a
parade permit within five hours after the filing thereof. If the Chief of
Police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant within
three days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of
his action, stating the reasons for his denial of the permit.



   (B)   Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial
of a parade permit to the Board of Trustees. The appeal shall be taken within
14 days after notice. The Board of Trustees shall act upon the appeal within
21 days after its receipt.



(Ord. 661, passed 6-1-70)



§ 95.07  ALTERNATING PERMIT.



   The Chief of Police, in denying an application for a parade permit,
shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a
time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An
applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within 30 days after
notice of the action o¥ the Chief of Police, file a written notice of
acceptance with the Chief of Police. An alternate parade permit shall conform
to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of a parade permit under,
this subchapter.



(Ord. 661, passed 6-1-70)



§ 95.08  INFORMATION REQUIRED WITHIN PERMIT.



   Each parade permit shall state the following information.



   (A)   Starting time;



   (B)   The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be
occupied by the parade;



   (C)   The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions
thereof; and



   (D)   Such other information as the Chief of Police shall find
necessary to the enforcement of this subchapter.



(Ord. 661, passed 6-1-70)



§ 95.09  PUBLIC CONDUCT DURING PARADES.



   (A)   Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct,
or impede, or interfere with any parade or parade assembly, or with any
person, vehicle, or animal participating or used in a parade.



   (B)   Driving through parades. No driver of a vehicle, street car,
or trackless trolley shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a
parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously
designated as a parade.



   (C)   Parking on parade route. The Chief of Police shall have the
authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of
vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of
a parade. The Chief of Police shall post signs to such effect, and it shall
be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in
violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street unposted
in violation of this subchapter.



(Ord. 661, passed 6-1-70)  Penalty, see § 95.99



PUBLIC GATHERINGS



§ 95.20  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   MASS GATHERING.  Any public gathering of people numbering 500 or more,
or 25% or more of the population of the village according to the last
preceding federal census, whichever is less.



(Ord. 916, passed 6-21-76)



§ 95.21  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   Except as otherwise provided in this subchapter, no mass gathering may
be set up, conducted, held, arranged, or promoted unless a written permit has
been issued by the Board of Trustees of the village at least 14 days in
advance of the proposed date of the gathering. This subchapter does not apply
to mass gatherings which are conducted, sponsored, promoted, or managed by a
governmental unit or agency, legally held on publicly owned land or property,
or by any eleemosynary associations so long as the same is not conducted for
pecuniary profit.



(Ord. 916, passed 6-21-76)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.22  APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.



   To obtain a permit to set up, hold, conduct, manage, arrange, or
promote any mass gatherings, the promoters must file written application
under oath on a form provided by the village which shall include the names
and addresses of the promoters, the location on which the mass gathering is
to be conducted, the nature or purpose of the mass gathering, the maximum
number of persons which the promoter plans to permit to assemble at any time,
the maximum number of tickets to be sold or given, and a statement that the
activities of the mass gatherings will not violate any village or county
zoning ordinances nor any village, county, or state health regulations. 
During the time and place where such mass gathering is to be held, the
promoters will provide suitable and adequate sanitary accommodations, medical
facilities, ambulance service, water supplies, safe and wholesome food, land
space, access and departure routes, parking, security and protection from
bodily harm and property damage to those expected to attend such mass
gathering.  The expenses for use of a reasonable number of policemen of the
village for control of traffic and persons attending the mass gathering, or
for the enforcement of the laws in connection herewith shall be paid by the
promoters prior to the issuance of a permit and shall file an application
with the Village Clerk together with an application fee of $100 at least 60
days prior to the proposed mass gathering.  At their next regularly
scheduled meeting of the Trustees of the village after the date of the filing
of said application, the Trustees will refer said application to the Chief of
Police and the Village Building Inspector for review to determine conformity
with this subchapter and written recommendations, including expenses for
policemen, which must be submitted to the Board of Trustees within 30 days
after such referral.



(Ord. 916, passed 6-21-76)



§ 95.23  PROOF OF INSURANCE REQUIRED.



   Prior to the issuance of a permit, the promoter shall furnish evidence
of health insurance for payment of any claims for personal injury including
death, property damage, or suits arising out of or in connection with such
mass gathering.  The minimum limits of such policy is to be $500,000 and
$1,000,000 and must name the village, its agents and representatives as
co-insured.



(Ord. 916, passed 6-21-76)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.24  BOND REQUIRED.



   Prior to the issuance of the permit, the person holding, managing,
conducting, or organizing such gathering shall provide and place on file with
the Village Clerk a corporate surety bond in the sum of $100,000, the surety
to be subject to approval of the village, which will indemnify, hold
harmless, and defend the village from any damages, costs, expenses,
attorney's fees caused or resulting from a violation of any ordinance of the
village by that person seeking to hold or conduct said gathering.



(Ord. 916, passed 6-21-76)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.25  STRUCTURE TO BE FREE FROM FIRE HAZARDS.



   No such gathering shall be held or promoted in any enclosed or
partially enclosed building, structure, or tent unless such premises have
been examined and approved by the Village Building Inspector and found to be
free from fire hazards and found to be suitable for such gatherings. No
structure enclosed by a roof shall be used unless same is constructed by
nonflammable material, provided, however, that tents or structures covered by
canvass or similar material may be used if the canvass or other material has
been properly treated to render it fire retardant.



(Ord. 916, passed 6-21-76)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.26  UNOBSTRUCTED EXITS REQUIRED ON PREMISES.



   Adequate unobstructed exits shall be provided on all premises used for
such gatherings to allow safe and rapid egress of all people attending, and
shall be at least three lineal feet of doorway or exit space for each 100
persons accommodated with a minimum of two separate exits located at least 30
feet from each other. All doors, gates, or points of egress shall open
outward. No such exit shall be constructed or locked so that egress from the
inside is prevented and no obstructions will be within 30 feet of each exit
way.



(Ord. 916, passed 6-21-76)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.27  CONSTRUCTION OF SEATS; NUMBER LIMITATION.



   (A)   All stands, seats, or rows of seating used for such gatherings
shall be so constructed as to be safe for the use designed and intended, and
shall be sufficiently strong to carry the same weight and stress as required
in the construction of seating and flooring for public stadium or auditorium
seats.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful to admit to any such premises a number of
persons to exceed the actual number of seats maintained for their
accommodations at a gathering.



(Ord. 916, passed 6-21-76)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.28  SANITARY FACILITIES REQUIRED; AMBULANCE.



   (A)   No such gathering shall be permitted on any premises or site
not equipped with adequate separate sanitary facilities for males and
females. Such facilities may be of the mechanical type rather than connected
with the public water and sewer system, provided that each separate facility
is serviced at least once each day. For purposes of this subchapter, two
separate sanitary units for each 100 persons in attendance is considered
adequate.



   (B)   If the public gathering is over 1,000 individuals, a staffed
ambulance is also required to be at or adjacent to the site of the intended
gathering.



(Ord. 916, passed 6-21-76)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.29  STAFF FOR EVENT.



   The promoter shall, in addition hereto, arrange for and provide for all
security officers, ticket takers, and parking attendants commensurate with
the size of the indicated activities.



(Ord. 916, passed 6-21-76)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.30  PERMITTED HOURS.



   Any such mass gathering shall be terminated no later than midnight. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to remain on the premises between the
hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m., provided that employees whose duties
necessitate it may remain on the premises for the performance of such duties.



(Ord. 916, passed 6-21-76)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.31  CERTAIN SOUNDS RESTRICTED.



   No sounds shall be emitted from any place of mass gathering in such
manner that said sound shall be audible  beyond the property lines of the
premises whereon the place of mass gathering is located. At no time shall
noise or sound emanate which, either by mechanical or electrical devices or
live performance, in any manner disturbs, annoys, injures, endangers, or
tends to disturb, annoy, injure, or endanger the comfort, repose, health,
peace, tranquility, or safety of persons or the public in general.



(Ord. 916, passed 6-21-76)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.99  PENALTY.



   (A)    Any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the
provisions of §§ 95.01 through 95.09 shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not
less than $5 nor exceeding $750; or shall be imprisoned for a period not
exceeding 30 days; or be both fined and imprisoned. 



(Ord. 661, passed 6-1-70)



   (B)   A violation of any terms or provisions of §§ 95.20 through
95.31 may subject the person to a fine of not less than $25 nor more than
$750 for every violation of these sections.  Each day that a violation of
these sections shall be permitted shall constitute a separate offense. 
Separate action may be commenced against each person organizing, managing,
conducting, controlling, and promoting said gathering including action
against said promoter and sureties to forfeit bond for all damages and
expenses incurred by the village for violation. 



(Ord. 916, passed 6-21-76)



(Am. Ord. 1943, passed 12-2-02)



CHAPTER 96:  STREETS AND SIDEWALKS



Section



General Provisions



   96.01   Open burning prohibited on public streets and ways



   96.02   Encroachments upon U.S. Route 45 right-of-way prohibited



   96.03   Encroachments upon U.S. Route 30 right-of-way prohibited



Skateboards on Public Rights-of-Way



   96.15   Skateboards on public rights of way



   96.16   Parental responsibility



   96.17   Resistance to police officer



 



   96.99   Penalty



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 96.01  OPEN BURNING PROHIBITED ON PUBLIC STREETS AND WAYS.



   It shall be unlawful to burn or incinerate any wood, brush, refuse,
garbage, paper, leaves or any other combustible material on any public
street, roadway, parking area, alley, parkway, sidewalk or street
right-of-way in the village.



(Ord. 1272, passed 9-5-89)  Penalty, see § 96.99



Cross-reference:



   Burning of leaves, see § 94.25



§ 96.02  ENCROACHMENTS UPON U.S. ROUTE 45 RIGHT-OF-WAY PROHIBITED.



   No person, firm, corporation or other entity shall install, place,
maintain or construct any structure that encroaches upon the State of
Illinois right-of-way on the U.S. Route 45 roadway within the village limits.



(Ord. 1326, passed 10-15-90; Am. Ord. 1662, passed 10-20-97; Am. Ord. 2525,
passed 10-20-08)



§ 96.03  ENCROACHMENTS UPON U.S. ROUTE 30 RIGHT-OF-WAY PROHIBITED.



   No person, firm, corporation or other entity shall install, place,
maintain or construct any structure that encroaches upon the State of
Illinois right-of-way on the U.S. Rouge 30 roadway from Wolf Road to IL Route
43 within the limits of the Village of Frankfort.



(Ord. 2500, passed 8-18-08; Am. Ord. 2705, passed 3-21-11)



SKATEBOARDS ON PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY



§ 96.15  SKATEBOARDS ON PUBLIC RIGHTS OF WAY.



   (A)   Definition.  The term SKATEBOARD, as used herein, shall
designate a platform supported by wheels intended to carry and support a
human foot and to be propelled by human foot power. It includes vehicles
containing a handle bar and sometimes referred to as scooters.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate, ride
upon, or propel a skateboard on any sidewalk located adjacent to any public
street or roadway, or upon any portion of any public street or roadway in the
following designated area:



      (1)   Nebraska Street from White Street to Hickory Street.



      (2)   Kansas Street from White Street to Hickory Street.



      (3)   Elwood Street from White Street to Oak Street.



      (4)   White Street from Nebraska Street to Elwood Street.



      (5)   Ash Street from Nebraska Street to Kansas Street.



      (6)   Oak Street from Nebraska Street to Elwood Street.



      (7)   Hickory Street from Nebraska Street to Kansas Street.



      (8)   Public Parking Area located at the corner of Oak Street
and Kansas Street.



      (9)   Public Parking Area located at the corner of Hickory and
Nebraska.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate, ride
upon, or propel a skateboard on or over any jumping device or ramp, or
similar structure on any public sidewalk, street or roadway, or public right
of way not so designated for such use by the Village Board of Trustees,
within the village.



   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate, ride upon
or propel a skateboard on or over any jumping device or ramp, or similar
structure on any portion of Breidert Green and the adjacent parking lot, or
on the Prairie Park parking lot, or on any other private property as posted
by a proprietor.



(Ord. 1264, passed 6-19-89; Am. Ord. 1943, passed 12-2-02)  Penalty, see §
96.99



§ 96.16  PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY.



   The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not
authorize or knowingly permit any child or ward to violate any provisions of
§ 96.15.  Any parent or guardian knowingly authorizing or permitting a
violation shall upon conviction thereof be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall
be punished in accordance with the provisions provided for in § 96.99.



(Ord. 1264, passed 6-19-89)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.17  RESISTANCE TO POLICE OFFICER.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to resist or obstruct any police
officer in enforcement of this subchapter.



(Ord. 1264, passed 6-19-89)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person convicted of violating any provision of § 96.01
shall be fined not less than $25 nor more than $750 for each offense.



(Ord. 1272, passed 9-5-89)



   (B)   The penalty for the violation of §§ 96.15 through 96.17
shall be not less than $15 nor more than $750 for each such offense.



(Ord. 1264, passed 6-19-89)



(Am. Ord. 1943, passed 12-2-02)



CHAPTER 97: OFF-ROAD RECREATIONAL VEHICLES



Section



General Provisions



   97.01   Definitions



Registration



   97.20   Operation of unregistered and unnumbered off-road vehicles
is prohibited



   97.21   Registration with the village



   97.22   Procedure for registration



   97.23   License fee



   97.24   Identification number display



   97.25   Exceptions from numbering display requirement



Off-Road Vehicle Equipment



   97.35   Equipment required



Control Provisions



   97.45   Operation



   97.46   Hours of operation



   97.47   Obedience to traffic regulations



   97.48   Youthful operators



   97.49   Prohibited acts



Enforcement



   97.60   Inspections authorized



   97.61   Resistance to police officer



 



   97.99   Penalty



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 97.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   COWLING.  The forward portions of the off-road vehicle surrounding the
motor and clutch assembly.



   DANGEROUS DRUG refers to any drug defined as a depressant or stimulant
substance in the "Illinois Controlled Substances Act," Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch.
56½, Par. 1100-1602 (1985).



   HIGHWAY means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way
publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public
for purposes of vehicular traffic.



   INTOXICATING BEVERAGE shall include spirits, wine, beer, ale and every
other liquid or solid containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer capable of
being consumed as a beverage by human beings.



   OFF-ROAD VEHICLE refers to a rubber tired self-propelled device
designed for travel over natural terrain, snow or ice operation on either
two, three or four wheels, specifically meaning including vehicles commonly
known as all-terrain vehicles (ATVs) or all-terrain cycles (ATCs) and dirt
bikes.  Off-Road Vehicles shall not include snowmobiles as defined in
Ordinance No. 1249.



   OPERATE.  To ride in or on, use or control the operation of an
off-road vehicle in any manner, whether or not said vehicle is underway.



   OPERATOR refers to every person who operates or is in actual physical
control of an off-road vehicle.



   OWNER.  A person, other than a lienholder, having title to an off-road
vehicle. The term includes a person entitled to the use or possession of an
off-road vehicle subject to an interest in another person, reserved or
created by agreement and securing payment or performance of an obligation,
but the term includes a lessee under a lease not intended as security.



   PERSON.  An individual, partnership, firm, corporation or association.



   REGISTER.  The act of assigning a registration number to an off-road
vehicle.



   ROADWAY refers to that portion of a street or highway improved,
designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the shoulder.



   VILLAGE refers to the Village of Frankfort, Will County, Illinois.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)



REGISTRATION



§ 97.20  OPERATION OF UNREGISTERED AND UNNUMBERED OFF-ROAD VEHICLES IS
PROHIBITED.



   Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall operate any off-road
vehicle within the village unless such vehicle has been registered and
numbered in accordance with this chapter.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)  Penalty, see § 97.99



§ 97.21  REGISTRATION WITH THE VILLAGE.



   Any resident of the village owning or acquiring an ownership interest
in an off-road vehicle stored, maintained or operated as provided herein
within the village, and any owner of an off-road vehicle operated as provided
herein within the village shall register the off-road vehicle each year that
said vehicle is stored, maintained or operated in the village on or before
the 30th day of June, A.D. 1989, or within ten days of the date of
acquisition of such vehicle, and shall do so on or before the 30th day of
June of each and every year thereafter, and on payment of the registration or
license fee hereinafter provided to the village, the Village Clerk shall
issue or cause to be issued a registration certificate or license authorizing
the storage, maintenance and/or operation of said vehicle within the village
until the expiration of such license. All registration certificates or
licenses shall expire on the first day of July of each year.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)  Penalty, see § 97.99



§ 97.22  PROCEDURE FOR REGISTRATION.



   Said residents and/or owners shall register the off-road vehicle with
the village on a form provided by the Village Clerk which shall contain (1)
the name of the registrant, (2) the registrant's address, (3) the
registrant's social security number, (4) the registrant's telephone number,
(5) a description of the vehicle being registered, and (6) the primary
operators of said vehicle.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)  Penalty, see § 97.99



§ 97.23  LICENSE FEE.



   The registration or license fee to be paid annually to the village
shall be $25 per off-road vehicle.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)



§ 97.24  IDENTIFICATION NUMBER DISPLAY.



   The owner shall paint on or securely attach to both sides of the
cowling of the off-road vehicle the identification number issued by the
village which shall be of block characters at least three inches in height. 
The characters shall read from left to right, be of contrasting color to
their background, and he maintained in a legible condition.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)  Penalty, see § 97.99



§ 97.25  EXCEPTIONS FROM NUMBERING DISPLAY REQUIREMENT.



   An off-road vehicle shall not be required to be numbered as provided in
§ 97.24 if it is:



   (A)   Owned and used by the United States, another state, or a
political subdivision thereof; but such off-road vehicles shall display the
name of the owner on the cowling thereof.



   (B)   Covered by a valid registration or license of another state,
province or country which is the domicile of the owner of the snowmobile and
is not operated within this state on more than 30 consecutive days in any
calendar year.



   (C)   Owned and operated on lands owned by the owner or operator or
on lands to which he has a contractual right other than as a member of a club
or association, provided the off-road vehicle is not operated elsewhere
within the state.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)  Penalty, see § 97.99



OFF-ROAD VEHICLE EQUIPMENT



§ 97.35  EQUIPMENT REQUIRED.



   All off-road vehicles operating within the municipality shall be
equipped with:



   (A)   At least one white headlamp having a minimum candlepower of
sufficient intensity to exhibit a white light plainly visible from a distance
of at least 500 feet ahead during hours of darkness under normal atmospheric
conditions.



   (B)   At least one red taillamp having a minimum candlepower of
sufficient intensity to exhibit a red light plainly visible from a distance
of 500 feet to the rear during hours of darkness under normal atmospheric
conditions.



   (C)   A brake system in good mechanical condition.



   (D)   Reflective material of a minimum area of 16 square inches
mounted on each side of the cowling.  Identifying numbers may be included in
computing the required 16 square inch area.



   (E)   Adequate sound suppression equipment. No off-road vehicle
shall be operated within the village, unless it is equipped with sound
suppression devices that limit total machine noise in accordance with noise
pollution standards established pursuant to the Environmental Protection Act.



   (F)   All off-road vehicles, while being operated within the
village, shall have attached to the rear thereof, at a convenient point, a
pole made of wood, metal, fiberglass, plastic, or similar material of
suitable nature eight feet in length which pole shall have attached to the
free end thereof a flag or pennant containing at least one square foot of a
bright or reflective material and visible at a distance of at least 100 feet.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)  Penalty, see § 97.99



CONTROL PROVISIONS



§ 97.45  OPERATION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any off-road
vehicle in the following ways:



   (A)   At a rate of speed in excess of 10 miles per hour while
operating an off-road vehicle within the village.



   (B)   At a rate of speed too fast for conditions; the fact that the
speed of the off-road vehicle does not exceed the applicable maximum speed
limit allowed does not relieve the driver from the duty to decrease speed as
may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person or vehicle or object
within legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care.



   (C)   In a careless, reckless or negligent manner.



   (D)   While under the influence of intoxicating beverages or
narcotic or dangerous drugs.



   (E)   At any time without at least one lighted headlamp and one
lighted taillamp on the off-road vehicle.



   (F)   On the tracks or right-of-way of any railroad.



   (G)   In any tree nursery or planting in a manner which damages or
destroys growing stock, or creates a substantial risk thereto.



   (H)   On private property, without the operator of the off-road
vehicle obtaining the written consent of the owner or lessee of the property
prior to operating the off-road vehicle upon lands of another shall stop and
identify himself upon the request of the landowner or his duly authorized
representative, and, if requested to do so by the landowner, shall promptly
remove the off-road vehicle from the premises.  Failure to post signs does
not imply consent for off-road vehicle use upon the property of the owner or
lessee.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)  Penalty, see § 97.99



§ 97.46  HOURS OF OPERATION.



   Off-road vehicles may be operated within the village only between the
hours of 10:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. each day of the week.  No such vehicle
may be operated within the village between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 9:00
a.m. on any day.  This section shall not prohibit the operation of off-road
vehicles between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. in cases of emergency
when the operator has specific authorization from the village, the Police
Department, or the Fire Department.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)  Penalty, see § 97.99



§ 97.47  OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC REGULATIONS.



   (A)   The maximum speed limit for operation of an off-road vehicle
within the village is ten miles per hour.



   (B)   Operators of off-road vehicles shall obey and abide by all
regulations prescribed for the operation of motor vehicles and shall be
subject to the same penalties for violation thereof, except as otherwise
provided herein.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)  Penalty, see § 97.99



§ 97.48  YOUTHFUL OPERATORS.



   (A)   No person under 14 years of age may operate an off-road
vehicle.



   (B)   Persons at least 6 years of age and less than 14 years of age
may operate an off-road vehicle within the village only if they are either
accompanied on the vehicle by a parent or guardian or a person at least 18
years of age designated by the parent or guardian.



   (C)   Violations of this section done with the knowledge of a parent
or guardian shall be deemed a violation by the parent or guardian and
punishable under § 97.99.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)  Penalty, see § 97.99



§ 97.49  PROHIBITED ACTS.



   (A)   No person, except persons permitted by law, shall operate or
ride any off-road vehicle with any firearm in his possession unless it is
unloaded and enclosed in a carrying case, or any bow unless it is unstrung in
a carrying case.



   (B)   No person shall operate any off-road vehicle emitting
pollutants in accordance with standards established pursuant to the
Environmental Protection Act.



   (C)   No person shall deposit from an off-road vehicle on the snow,
ice, or ground surface, trash, glass, garbage, insoluble material, or other
offensive matter.



   (D)   No person shall use an off-road vehicle to take, pursue,
chase, harass or disturb wildlife and other animals, including dogs and cats,
within the village.



   (E)   No person except persons provided by law shall operate or ride
an off-road vehicle on, upon or across any public street, alley, right of
way, road, highway, parkway, sidewalk or other public property within the
corporate limits of the Village of Frankfort.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)  Penalty, see § 97.99



ENFORCEMENT



§ 97.60  INSPECTIONS AUTHORIZED.



   (A)   Duly authorized police officers may stop and inspect any
off-road vehicle at any time for the purpose of determining if the provisions
of this chapter are being complied with.  If the inspecting officer or agent
discovers any violation of the provisions of this chapter, he must issue a
summons to the operator of such vehicle requiring that the operator appear
before the proper court.



   (B)   Every off-road vehicle operated within the village, if under
way and upon being hailed by a designated law enforcement officer, must stop
immediately.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)



§ 97.61  RESISTANCE TO POLICE OFFICER.



   It is unlawful for any person to resist or obstruct any police in
enforcement of this chapter.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88)



§ 97.99  PENALTY.



   Any person convicted of violating any provision of this chapter shall
be subject to a fine of not less than $100 nor more than $750, and shall be
fined for a second conviction not less that $300 nor more than $750.



(Ord. 1220, passed 6-20-88; Am. Ord. 1943, passed 12-2-02)



CHAPTER 98: SNOWMOBILES



Section



General Provisions



   98.01   Definitions



Registration



   98.20   Operation of unregistered and unnumbered snowmobiles is
prohibited



   98.21   Registration with the village



   98.22   Procedure for registration



   98.23   License fee



   98.24   Identification number display



   98.25   Exceptions from numbering display requirement



Snowmobile Equipment



   98.35   Equipment required



Control Provisions



   98.45   Operation



   98.46   Operation on highways



   98.47   Hours of operation



   98.48   Snowmobile trails



   98.49   Obedience to traffic regulations



   98.50   Youthful operators



   98.51   Prohibited acts



Enforcement



   98.60   Inspections authorized



   98.61   Resistance to police officer



 



   98.99   Penalty



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 98.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   COWLING.  The forward portions of a snowmobile surrounding the motor
and clutch assembly.



   DANGEROUS DRUG refers to any drug defined as a depressant or stimulant
substance in the "Illinois Controlled Substances Act," III. Rev. Stat. Ch.
56½, par. 1100-1602 (1985).



   HIGHWAY.  The entire width between the boundary lines of every federal
and state numbered public way maintained when any part thereof is open to the
use of the public for purposes of vehicular traffic.



   INTOXICATING BEVERAGE shall include spirits, wine, beer, ale and every
other liquid or solid containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer capable of
being consumed as a beverage by human beings.



   OPERATE.  To ride in or on, use or control the operation of a
snowmobile in any manner, whether or not the snowmobile is underway.



   OPERATOR refers to every person who operates or is in actual physical
control of a snowmobile.



   OWNER.  A person, other than a lienholder, having title to a
snowmobile.  The term includes a person entitled to the use or possession of
a snowmobile subject to an interest in another person, reserved or created by
agreement and securing payment or performance of an obligation, but the term
includes a lessee under a lease not intended as security.



   PERSON.  An individual, partnership, firm, corporation or association.



   REGISTER.  The act of assigning a registration number to a snowmobile.



   ROADWAY refers to that portion of a street or highway improved,
designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the shoulder.



   SNOWMOBILE.  A self-propelled device designed for travel over snow or
ice or natural terrain steered by skis or runners, and supported in part by
skis, belts or cleats.



   VILLAGE refers to the Village of Frankfort, Will County, Illinois.



   STREET.  The entire width of a public right-of-way used or planned for
use for vehicular traffic and maintained by the local jurisdiction of the
county, township or municipality.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)



REGISTRATION



§ 98.20  OPERATION OF UNREGISTERED AND UNNUMBERED SNOWMOBILES IS PROHIBITED.



   Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall operate any snowmobile
within the village unless such snowmobile has been registered and numbered in
accordance with the provisions of the Illinois "Snowmobile Registration and
Safety Act", Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 95½, sec. 601-1 et seq. (1985), and the
provisions hereinafter set forth and unless the Certificate of Number awarded
to such snowmobile is in full force and effect.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)  Penalty, see § 98.99



§ 98.21  REGISTRATION WITH THE VILLAGE.



   Any owner and/or operator of a snowmobile within the village shall
register the snowmobile each year that the snowmobile is operated in the
village beginning on a date not more than 30 days from the date of adoption
of this ordinance and shall do so an or before the 30th day of June of each
and every year thereafter, or within ten days of the date of acquisition of a
snowmobile, and on payment of the registration of license fee hereinafter
provided to the village, the Village Clerk shall issue or cause to be issued
a registration certificate or license authorizing the operation of such
license.  All registration certificates or licenses shall expire on the 1st
day of July of each year.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)  Penalty, see § 98.99



§ 98.22  PROCEDURE FOR REGISTRATION.



   Said residents and/or owners shall register the snowmobile with the
village on a form provided by the Village Clerk which shall contain (1) the
name of the registrant, (2) the registrant's address, (3) the registrant's
social security number, (4) the registrant's telephone number, (5) a
description of the snowmobile being registered, (6) the number awarded to the
snowmobile by the Department of Conservation and contained on the Certificate
of Number issued by said Department, (7) the primary operators of said
snowmobile, and (8) proof of insurance for liability and property damage.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)  Penalty, see § 98.99



§ 98.23  LICENSE FEE.



   The registration or license fee to be paid annually to the village
shall be $25 per snowmobile.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)



§ 98.24  IDENTIFICATION NUMBER DISPLAY.



   The owner shall paint on or securely attach to both sides of the
cowling of the snowmobile the identification number, as set forth on the
Certificate of Number, which shall be of block characters at least three
inches in height.  The characters shall read from left to right, be of
contrasting color to their background, and be maintained in a legible
condition.  The Certificate of Number shall be available at all times or
inspection on the snowmobile for which it was issued, whenever the snowmobile
is in operation.  In addition, the operator must wear a vest with a matching
number to the I.D. number issued for the snowmobile.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)  Penalty, see § 98.99



§ 98.25  EXCEPTIONS FROM NUMBERING DISPLAY REQUIREMENT.



   A snowmobile shall not be required to be numbered as provided in §
98.24 if it is:



   (A)   Owned and used by the United States, another state, or a
political subdivision thereof; but such snowmobiles shall display the name of
the owner on the cowling thereof.



   (B)   Used only on international or national competition circuits in
events for which written permission has been obtained by the sponsoring or
sanctioning body from the governmental unit having jurisdiction over the
location of any event held in this state.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)



SNOWMOBILE EQUIPMENT



§ 98.35  EQUIPMENT REQUIRED.



   All snowmobiles operating within the municipality shall be equipped
with:



   (A)   At least one white headlamp having a minimum candlepower of
sufficient intensity to exhibit a white light plainly visible from a distance
of at least 500 feet ahead during hours of darkness under normal atmospheric
conditions.



   (D)   At least one red taillamp having a minimum candlepower of
sufficient intensity to exhibit a red light plainly visible from a distance
of 500 feet to the rear during hours of darkness under normal atmospheric
conditions.



   (C)   A brake system in good mechanical condition.



   (D)   Reflective material of a minimum area of 16 square inches
mounted on each side of the cowling.  Identifying numbers may be included in
computing the required 16 square inch area.



   (E)   Adequate sound suppression equipment. No snowmobile shall be
operated within the village, unless it is equipped with sound suppression
devices that limit total machine noise in accordance with noise pollution
standards established pursuant to The Environmental Protection Act. 
Operation during repair of a snowmobile shall be excepted from this
subsection.



   (F)   All snowmobiles, while being operated within the village,
shall have attached to the rear thereof, at a convenient point, a pole made
of wood, metal, fiberglass, plastic, or similar material of suitable nature
eight feet in length which pole shall have attached to the free end thereof a
flag or pennant containing at least one square foot of bright or reflective
material and visible at a distance of at least 100 feet.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)  Penalty, see § 98.99



CONTROL PROVISIONS



§ 98.45  OPERATION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any snowmobile
in the following ways:



   (1)   At a rate of speed no greater than the minimum speed required
to maintain forward movement of the snowmobile, which is considered to be
less than 10 m.p.h. operating a snowmobile within the village.



   (2)   At a rate of speed too fast for conditions; the fact that the
speed of the snowmobile does not exceed the applicable maximum speed limit
allowed does not relieve the driver from the duty to decrease speed as may be
necessary to avoid colliding with any person or vehicle or object within
legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care.



   (3)   In a careless, reckless or negligent manner.



   (4)   While under the influence of intoxicating beverages or
narcotic or dangerous drugs.



   (5)   At any time without at least one lighted headlamp and one
lighted taillamp on the snowmobile.



   (6)   On the tracks or right-of-way of an operating railroad.



   (7)   In any tree nursery or planting in a manner which damages or
destroys growing stock, or creates a substantial risk thereto.



   (8)   On private property, within the village corporate limits or an
public or private properties adjacent to the corporate boundaries of the
village.



   (9)   Within 40 feet of a residential dwelling between 9:00 a.m. and
11:00 p.m. at a speed no greater than the minimum speed required to maintain
forward movement of the snowmobile, which is considered to be less than 10
m.p.h.



   (10)   On the frozen waters within the village in a manner
inconsistent with the Rules and Regulations of the Illinois Department of
Conservation.



   (11)   To operate a snowmobile within the village when, immediately
during said period of time, the accumulation of snow existing on the ground
during that time is less than the depth of two inches as measured by the
village and reported on cable television, Channel 10.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)  Penalty, see § 98.99



§ 98.46  OPERATION ON HIGHWAYS.



   It is unlawful for any person to drive or operate any snowmobile on a
highway in the village except as follows:



   (A)   On highways other than tollways, interstate highways and fully
or limited access-controlled highways, snowmobiles may make a direct crossing
provided:



      (1)   The crossing is made at an angle of approximately 90
degrees to the direction of the highway and at a place where no obstruction
prevents a quick and safe crossing; and



      (2)   The snowmobile is brought to a complete stop before
crossing a roadway; and



      (3)   The operator yields the right-of-way to all oncoming
traffic which constitutes a hazard.



   (B)   On highways other than tollways, interstate highways, and
fully or limited access-controlled highways snowmobiles may be operated not
less than 20 feet from the roadway and in the same direction as traffic
except as hereinafter provided.



   (C)   On highways other than tollways, interstate highways, and
fully or limited access-controlled highways snowmobiles may be operated on
roadways when it is necessary to cross a bridge or culvert or when it is
impracticable to gain immediate access to an area adjacent to a highway where
a snowmobile is to be operated.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)



§ 98.47  HOURS OF OPERATION.



   Snowmobiles may be operated within the village hereinabove provided
only upon the snowmobile trails hereinafter designated and only between the
hours of  5:00 p.m. and 11:00 p.m. Monday through Friday and 9:00 a.m. and
11:00 p.m. Saturday, Sunday, holidays and school closings.  No snowmobile
may be operated within the village between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 9:00
a.m. on any day.  This section shall not prohibit the operation of
snowmobiles between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. in cases of
emergency when the operator has specific authorization from the village, the
Police Department, or the Fire Department.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)



§ 98.48  SNOWMOBILE TRAILS.



   (A)   The following street right of ways or parts thereof in the
village are designated as snowmobile trails within the village and are the
only authorized trails upon which snowmobiles may be operated within five
feet of either side of the roadway edge and in the same direction as traffic:



      (1)   Colorado, Indiana and Cedar between Route 43 and Route
30.



      (2)   Elsner Road between Route 30 and Route 45.



      (3)   92nd Ave Row and Larch St. between Route 30 and Sauk
Trail.



      (4)   Route 30 and Route 45.



      (5)   Nebraska St. between Larch and Route 45.



      (6)   Center Road South of Nebraska St.



      (7)   Sauk Trail east of Center Road.



   (B)   Only those public right of ways or parts thereof, herein
designated as snowmobiles trails shall be used for the operation of
snowmobiles in the village, and no snowmobile shall be operated on any other
street within the village.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)



§ 98.49  OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC REGULATIONS.



   (A)   The maximum speed limit for operation of a snowmobile within
the village is at a speed no greater than the minimum required to maintain
forward movement of the snowmobile, considered to be less than 10 m.p.h.



   (B)   Operators of snowmobiles shall obey and abide by all traffic
regulations prescribed for the operation of motor vehicles and shall be
subject to the same penalties for violation thereof, except as otherwise
provided herein.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)



§ 98.50  YOUTHFUL OPERATORS.



   (A)   No person under ten years of age may operate a snowmobile.



   (B)   Persons at least ten years of age and less than 12 years of
age may operate a snowmobile within the village only if they are either
accompanied on the snowmobile by a parent or guardian, or a person at least
18 years of age designated by the parent or guardian.



   (C)   Persons at least 12 and less than 16 years of age may operate
a snowmobile only if they are either accompanied on the snowmobile by a
parent or guardian or a person at least 16 years of age designated by a
parent or guardian, or such operator is in possession of a certificate issued
by the Illinois Department of Conservation authorizing the holder to operate
snowmobiles.



   (D)   Any person who operates a snowmobile on a highway as provided
in § 98.46 or on the snowmobile trails designated in § 98.48 shall possess
a valid motor vehicle driver's license or a safety certification issued by
the Illinois Department of Conservation.



   (E)   Violations of this section done with the knowledge of a parent
or guardian shall be deemed a violation by the parent or guardian and
punishable under § 98.99.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)  Penalty, see § 98.99



§ 98.51  PROHIBITED ACTS.



   (A)   No person, except persons permitted by law, shall operate or
ride any snowmobile with any firearm in his possession.



   (B)   No person shall operate any snowmobile emitting pollutants in
accordance with standards established pursuant to the Environmental
Protection Act.



   (C)   No person shall deposit from a snowmobile on the snow, ice, or
ground surface, trash, glass, garbage, insoluble material, or other offensive
matter.



   (D)   No person shall use a snowmobile to take, pursue, chase,
harass or disturb wildlife and other animals, including dogs and cats.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)  Penalty, see § 98.99



ENFORCEMENT



§ 98.60  INSPECTIONS AUTHORIZED.



   (A)   Duly authorized police officers may stop and inspect any
snowmobile at any time for the purpose of determining compliance with this
chapter.  If the inspecting officer or agent discovers any violation of the
provisions of this chapter, the officer shall issue a summons to the operator
of such snowmobile requiring that the operator appear before the proper court.



   (B)   Every snowmobile operated within the village, if under way and
upon being hailed by a designated law enforcement officer, must stop
immediately.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)  Penalty, see § 98.99



§ 98.61  RESISTANCE TO POLICE OFFICER.



   It is unlawful for any person to resist or obstruct any police in
enforcement of this chapter.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98)  Penalty, see § 98.99



§ 98.99  PENALTY.



   Any person convicted of violating any provision of this chapter shall
be subject to a fine of not less than $100 nor more than $750 and shall be
fined for a second conviction not less than $300 nor more than $750.  A
third arrest will result in confiscation of the snowmobile with a third
conviction prohibiting the operator from licensing the vehicle for a period
not to exceed two years.



(Ord. 1249, passed 12-5-98; Am. Ord. 1943, passed 12-2-02)



CHAPTER 99: FIREWORKS



Section



   99.01   Definitions



   99.02   Prohibited conduct



   99.03   Pyrotechnic displays



   99.04   Permit application and procedures



   99.05   Notice to the village



   99.06   Record of permits issued



 



   99.99   Penalty



§ 99.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purposes of this chapter, the definitions contained in the
Fireworks Use Act (ILCS Ch. 425, Act 35, §§ 1 et seq.) and the Pyrotechnic
and Consumer Display Permitting Rules (41 Ill. Adm. Code 235.10 et seq.)
shall apply unless the context otherwise requires.



(Ord. 2286, passed 6-5-06)



§ 99.02  PROHIBITED CONDUCT.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision
of the Fireworks Use Act or any rule or regulation promulgated by the State
Fire Marshal pursuant to the Fireworks Use Act. Except as hereinafter
provided, it shall be unlawful for any person, firm, co-partnership or
