§ 113.18.2  LIVE ENTERTAINMENT.



   No live entertainment may be present upon any premises where alcoholic
liquor is sold or offered for sale at retail with the exception that it may
be permitted under Classes A-1, B-1, C, D-1, D-2, E, G, H and I-1, I-2, I-3,
M, and N provided, however, that the applicant desiring to present live
entertainment at the time of the making of application hereunder for any such
class of license shall disclose on the application therefore, the fact that
such entertainment shall be presented, the type and nature of such
entertainment and shall pay an additional fee which shall be set from time to
time by the Board of Trustees. In the event the Liquor Commissioner shall in
his or her sole discretion desire to permit live entertainment on such
premises, he or she shall so indicate in writing and any such license issued
shall on the face thereto indicate that “live entertainment is
permitted.”  In the even the Liquor Commission shall in his or her sole
discretion deny such application for live entertainment, he or she shall so
indicate in writing on the application and the applicant shall be so advised
within a reasonable period of time.  Notwithstanding the foregoing, live
entertainment on any licensed premises in the Frankfort Historical District
shall, if permitted, be restricted to the following days and times:



   (A)   On Wednesdays and Thursdays, live entertainment will be
permitted upon the premises of the licensee until 10:30 p.m. On Friday and
Saturday live entertainment will be permitted until 1:00 a.m.;



   (B)   On Sundays, live entertainment will be permitted upon the
premises of the licensee until 8:00 p.m.; and



   (C)   No live entertainment will be permitted in the Frankfort
Historical District on Mondays and Tuesdays; nor will live entertainment
heard from the outside of the premises of the licensee be permitted on Sunday
evenings during presentation of Frankfort’s Concerts-on-the-Green.



   (D)   Whenever live entertainment is permitted, the level of noise
shall not exceed 55 decibels prior to 10:30 p.m. and 45 decibels from 10:30
p.m. until time of closing.



   (E)   All public address systems broadcasting outdoors must be
turned off in conformity with the live entertainment.



(Am. Ord. 2958, passed 12-15-14; Am. Ord. 3017, passed 3-21-16; Am. Ord.
3025, passed 4-25-16; Am. Ord. 3039, passed 7-18-16; Am. Ord. 3063, passed
10-17-16; Am. Ord. 3126, passed 12-18-17)



§ 113.19  ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.



   When the Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall approve any
application, the applicant shall be issued a license upon the payment in
advance of the required fee, which license shall be in writing over the name
and under the seal of the village and executed by the President of the
Village and attested by the Village Clerk.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)



§ 113.20  LIMITATION ON NUMBER OF LICENSES.



   (A)   There shall be available for issuance the following number of
licenses for each of the following classifications:



      (1)   There shall be issued in the village not more than one
Class A-1 license and not more than zero Class A-2 license.



      (2)   There shall be issued in the village not more than one
Class B-1 and not more than one Class B-2 licenses.



      (3)   There shall be issued in the village not more than nine
Class C-1 licenses and not more than six Class C-2 licenses.



      (4)   There shall be issued in the village not more than one
Class D-l licenses and not more than one Class D-2 licenses.



      (5)   There shall be issued in the village not more than three
Class E-l licenses, one Class E-2, and two Class E-3 licenses.



      (6)   There shall be issued in the village not more than zero
Class F-1 licenses, three Class F-2 licenses, zero Class F-3 licenses, three
Class F-4 licenses, and one Class F-5 license.



      (7)   There shall be issued in the village not more than zero
Class G licenses.



      (8)   There shall be issued in the village not more than one
Class H license.



      (9)   There is no limitation upon the number of Class I-1
licenses, but their issuance is entirely within the reasonable discretion of
the Local Liquor Control Commissioner; not more than zero Class I-2 and zero
Class I-3.



      (10)   There shall be issued in the village not more than one
Class J license.



      (11)   There shall be issued in the village not more than one
Class K license.



      (12)   There shall be issued in the village not more than zero
Class L license.



      (13)   There shall be issued in the village not more than zero
Class M licenses.



      (14)   There shall be issued in the village not more than zero
Class N licenses.



   (B)   No more than ten liquor licenses shall be issued to persons,
firms or corporations to sell or offer for sale at retail, alcoholic liquor
within the Frankfort Historical District. The classification and number of
liquor licenses which may be issued for use in the Frankfort Historical
District are as follows:



      (1)   Not more than one Class A-l license.



      (2)   Not more than one Class B-l license.



      (3)   Not more than three Class C-l licenses and two C-2
licenses.



      (4)   Not more than one Class D-2 license.



      (5)   Not more than one Class E-l license and one E-3 license.



      (6)   Not more than zero Class F licenses.



      (7)   Not more than zero Class G licenses.



      (8)   Not more than zero Class H licenses.



      (9)   There is no limitation upon the number of Class I
licenses; not more than zero Class I-2 and zero Class I-3 licenses.



      (10)   Not more than zero Class J licenses.



      (11)   Not more than zero Class K licenses.



      (12)   Not more than zero Class L licenses.



      (13)   Not more than zero Class M licenses.



      (14)   Not more than zero Class N licenses.

§ 113.20.1  LICENSE NOTIFICATION REQUIREMENTS.



   Not later than the day of:



   (A)   The cessation of a business licensed under this chapter; or



   (B)   The cessation of the sale of alcoholic liquor by a business
licensed under this chapter; or



   (C)   The sale, transfer, assignment or alienation of any interest
in a business licensed under this chapter, the liquor licensee shall
immediately notify the Village of Frankfort Liquor Control Commissioner, the
Village Clerk and the Village Administrator of the event in writing by either
personal service or by certified U.S. Mail (return-receipt requested),
separately addressed to each at the Village of Frankfort Administrative
Center.



(Ord. 2710, passed 4-18-11)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.21  DURATION OF LICENSE; PRORATION OF FEE.



   (A)   No license shall be issued under this chapter for a period of
less than one calendar year, unless the same is issued pursuant to
application made subsequent to the first day of any calendar year, in which
event the license shall be issued for the remaining period of the year, and
no license shall be issued for a period of more than one year. Unless
otherwise provided by law, all licenses issued hereunder shall be valid from
January 1 or the date of issuance, whichever comes later, to December 31 of
each year.



   (B)   For all licenses issued and in effect on or before June 30 of
each year, the full fee shall be paid. For all licenses issued on or after
July 1 of each year, the fee shall be 50% of the annual fee as hereinbefore
established. All license fees shall be paid to the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner at the time the application is made and shall be forthwith
turned over to the Village Treasurer. The required fee shall be submitted
with the application. If the license is granted, then the fee shall be
deposited in a general corporate fund or in such other funds as shall have
been designated by the Village Board of Trustees by proper action.



   (C)   Upon a business licensed under this chapter either:



      (1)   Closing or otherwise ceasing to do business; or



      (2)   Discontinuing or ceasing the sale of alcoholic liquor,
the liquor license issued to its licensee shall automatically terminate and
become null and void and the number of available liquor licenses authorized
in the classification (class) of the terminated license shall automatically
be reduced by one.



   (D)   Upon the sale, transfer, assignment or any other alienation of
any interest of any business licensed under this chapter, the liquor license
issued to its licensee shall automatically terminate and become null and void
and the number of available liquor licenses authorized in the classification
(class) of the terminated license shall automatically be reduced by one.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83; Am. Ord. 2274, passed 4-3-06; Am. Ord. 2710,
passed 4-18-11)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.22  RENEWAL.



   Any licensee may apply to renew his license at the expiration thereof,
provided he is then qualified to receive a license and the premises for which
such renewal license is sought are suitable for such purposes, and provided
further that the renewal privilege herein provided for shall not be construed
as a vested right which shall in any case prevent the President and Board of
Trustees of the village from decreasing the number of licenses to be issued
within the village.  However, when the number of applications made for a
liquor license, or for any class of license, exceeds the number of licenses
permitted under this chapter, prior licenses shall be given preference over
new applicants provided such prior licenses otherwise qualify for such
license.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)



§ 113.23  POSTING OF LICENSE.



   The license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be posted in a
prominent place within the licensed premises.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.24  CHANGE OF LOCATION.



   Licenses issued hereunder shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor
only in the premises described in the application for license.  Such
location may be changed only upon the written permit to make such change,
issued by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner.  No change of location
shall be permitted unless the proposed new location is a proper one for the
retail sale of alcoholic liquor under the laws of the state and the
ordinances of this village.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.25  SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE.



   (A)   In addition to all other fines and penalties, the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner may suspend or revoke the retail liquor dealer’s
license for any violation of this chapter.



   (B)   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner may suspend for not more
than 30 days (ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, § 4-4) or may revoke for cause, any
license issued by him if he determines that the licensee has violated any of
the provisions of “the Liquor Control Act of 1934,” ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5,
1-1 et seq., as it now exists and may hereafter be amended or the provisions
of this chapter or any rule or regulation established by the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner or State Liquor Commissioner, which is not inconsistent
with law, all in the manner and as provided in ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, § 7-5.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)



§ 113.26  UNLAWFUL DENIAL OF USE OF ACCOMMODATIONS AND PRIVILEGES BY AGENTS
OR EMPLOYEES OF LICENSEE.



   No licensee under the provisions of this chapter shall deny or permit
his agents and employees to deny any person the full and equal enjoyment of
the accommodations, advantagements, facilities, and privileges on any
premises in which alcoholic liquors are authorized to be sold subject only to
the conditions and limitations established by law and applicable alike to all
citizens.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)  Penalty, see § 113.99



RETAIL SALES



§ 113.35  RESPONSIBILITY FOR PROPER OPERATION OF BUSINESS.



   The licensee and its associates, members, representatives, agents,
officers and employees, shall at all times be personally responsible for the
proper operation of the business, including compliance with the provisions of
this chapter and the observation of all laws and regulations applicable
thereto.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)



§ 113.36  HOURS OF SALES.



Note:   The normal hours of operation for a business within the village
are 7:00 a.m. until 11:00 p.m. Establishments with operating hours outside of
these normal operating hours must be approved as a special use according to
the regulations of Article 3, Section E of the Zoning Ordinance. (Excerpted
from the Village of Frankfort Zoning Ordinance 2001, Article 6, Section C,
Part 2, paragraph q, Hours of Operation.)



   (A)   No licensee shall keep open or allow his or her place of
business to remain open or sell or offer for sale at retail, or offer to give
away on any licensed premises, any alcoholic liquor in the village between
the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. The sale of alcoholic liquors shall
cease immediately at the aforesaid hour of 1:00 a.m.



   (B)   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner may, in his or her
discretion, further reasonably restrict the above general hours during which
any licensee may keep open or allow his or her place of business to remain
open, or sell, offer for sale or give away any alcoholic liquor on any
licensed premises when, in the Local Liquor Control Commissioner's judgment,
a further restriction would be in the best interest of the public and the
village and in furtherance of the general welfare and safety thereof. Any
license so further restricted as to time shall, when issued, indicate on the
face thereof the hours during which the licensee thereunder may keep open or
allow his or her place of business to remain open as aforesaid.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83; Am. Ord. 2274, passed 4-3-06; Am. Ord. 2545,
passed 12-1-08; Am. Ord. 2826, passed 1-7-13; Am. Ord. 2831, passed
2-19-13)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.37  CLOSING HOURS FOR LICENSED PREMISES.



   (A)   No member of the general public shall remain in or upon the
licensed premises after the hour of 1:00 a.m. Should any person be found upon
or leaving the licensed premises after the hour of 1:00 a.m., the village
shall have the right to presume that such person was served alcoholic liquor
after the hour of 1:00 a.m. and such presumption may be raised in any court
in a proceeding for violation of the terms of this chapter or at any hearing
concerning the revocation of the license issued to the licensee of the
premises in question. Further, with regard to any license restricted by the
Local Liquor Control Commissioner to a closing time different than the
general hours set forth in § 113.36 hereof, the above and foregoing
provisions of this section shall apply and shall be construed to mean the
closing time indicated on said license which is so further restricted as to
time.



   (B)   Nothing in division (A) of this section shall apply to the
licensee, members of his or her family or his or her employees, agents or
servants if found upon or leaving the licensed premises after the hour of
1:00 a.m., nor shall division (A) of this section apply to premises which
have been granted a Class F-2 or F-3 or F-5 liquor license.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83; Am. Ord. 2274, passed 4-3-06; Am. Ord. 2826,
passed 1-7-13)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.38  PREMISES TO BE KEPT IN SANITARY CONDITION.



   All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor or for the
storage of such liquor for such sale, shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition and shall be kept in full compliance with the ordinances regulating
the condition of premises used for the storage or sale of food for human
consumption.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.39  CONTAGIOUS DISEASES AMONG EMPLOYEES.



   It shall be unlawful to employ in any premises used for the sale of
alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with, or who is a carrier of any
contagious, infectious or venereal disease; and it shall be unlawful for any
person who is afflicted with or a carrier of any such diseases to work in or
about any premises or to engage in any way in the handling, preparation or
distribution of such liquor.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.40  USE OF SLOT MACHINES, PINBALL MACHINES, AND OTHER DEVICES.



   It shall be unlawful to keep, have, use or permit to be used in any
premises in the village, used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, any
slot machine, pinball machine, video game or other instrument device upon
which money is staked or hazarded or into which money is paid or played upon
chance, or upon the result of the action of which money or other valuable
thing is staked, bet, won or lost.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)  Penalty, see § 113.99



2009 S-15



§ 113.41  LIVE ENTERTAINMENT; UNDESIRABLE ELEMENTS OR DISORDERLY CONDUCT
PROHIBITED.



   (A)   No live entertainment may be present upon any premises where
alcoholic liquor is sold or offered for sale at retail with the exception
that it may be permitted under Classes A-l, B-l, C, D-l, D-2, E, F, G, H I-1,
I-2, I-3, M, and N provided, however, that the applicant desiring to present
live entertainment at the time of the making of application hereunder for any
such class of license shall disclose on the application therefore, the fact
that such entertainment shall be presented, the type and nature of such
entertainment and shall pay an additional fee which shall be set from time to
time by the Board of Trustees.



   (B)   In the event the Liquor Commissioner shall in his sole
discretion desire to permit live entertainment on such premises, he shall so
indicate in writing and any such license issued shall on the face thereto
indicate that “live entertainment is permitted.”  In the event the
Liquor Commission shall in his sole discretion deny such application for live
entertainment, he shall so indicate in writing on the application and the
applicant shall be so advised within a reasonable period of time.



   (C)   Notwithstanding the foregoing, live entertainment on any
premises in the Frankfort Historical District shall, if permitted, be
restricted to the following days and times:



      (1)   On Wednesdays and Thursdays, live entertainment will be
permitted upon the premises of the licensee until 10:30 p.m.  On Friday and
Saturday live entertainment will be permitted until 1:00 a.m.



      (2)   On Sundays, live entertainment will be permitted upon
the premises of the licensee until 8:00 p.m.



      (3)   No live entertainment will be permitted in the Frankfort
Historical District on Mondays and Tuesdays; nor will live entertainment
heard from outside of the premises of the licensee be permitted on Sunday
evenings during presentation of Frankfort’s Concerts-on the-Green.



      (4)   Whenever live entertainment is permitted, the level of
noise shall not exceed 55 decibels prior to 10:30 p.m. and 45 decibels from
10:30 p.m. until time of closing.



      (5)   All public address systems broadcasting outdoors must be
turned off in conformity with the live entertainment.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83; Am. Ord. 1703, passed 6-1-98; Am. Ord. 2545,
passed 12-1-08; Am. Ord. 3039, passed 7-18-16; Am. Ord. 3063, passed
10-17-16; Am. Ord. 3126, passed 12-18-17)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.42  SALES NEAR CHURCHES, SCHOOL AND THE LIKE.



   No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic
liquor within 100 feet of any church, school, other than an institution of
higher learning, hospital, home for the aged or indigent persons or for
veterans, their spouses or children or any military or naval station,
provided that this prohibition shall not apply to hotels offering restaurant
service, regularly organized clubs or to restaurants, food shops or other
places where sale of alcoholic liquors is not the principal business carried
on, if such place of business so exempted shall have been established for
such purposes prior to the taking effect of this chapter; nor to the renewal
of a license for the sale at retail of alcoholic liquor on premises within
100 feet of any church or school where such church or school shall be
measured to the nearest part of any building used for worship services or
educational programs and not to property boundaries.  Nothing in this
section shall prohibit the issuance of a license to a church or private
school to sell at retail alcoholic liquor if any such sales are limited to
periods when groups are assembled on the premises solely for the promotion of
some common object other than the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquors.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.43  SALES IN CERTAIN PREMISES PROHIBITED.



   No license shall be issued for the purpose of selling or offering for
sale at retail any intoxicating liquor in any dwelling, house, flat or
apartment building.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.44  SALE TO MINORS OR INTOXICATED PERSONS; EXCEPTION.



   No licensee nor any officer, associate, member, representative, agent
or employee of such licensee shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to
any person under the age of 21 years, or to any intoxicated person, or to any
person known by him to be a habitual drunkard, spendthrift, insane, mentally
ill, mentally deficient or in need of mental treatment.  No person after
purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor shall sell, give or
deliver such alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of 21 years,
except in the performance of a religious ceremony or service.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.45  SEALING AND REMOVAL OF OPEN WINE BOTTLES.



   Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, a restaurant
licensed to sell alcoholic liquor in the village may permit a patron to
remove one unsealed and partially consumed bottle of wine for off- premise
consumption provided that the patron has purchased a meal and consumed a
portion of the bottle of wine with the meal on the restaurant premises. A
partially consumed bottle of wine that is so removed from the premises
pursuant to this section shall be securely sealed by the licensee or an agent
of the licensee prior to removal from the premises and placed in a
transparent one-time use tamper-proof bag. The licensee or agent of the
licensee shall provide a dated receipt for the bottle of wine to the patron.



(Ord. 2395, passed 6-18-07)  Penalty, see § 113.99



PERSONS 21 YEARS AND UNDER



§ 113.55  DISPLAY OF NOTICE.



   In every tavern or other place in the village where alcoholic liquor is
sold there shall be displayed at all times in a prominent place a printed
card which shall read substantially as follows:



   WARNING TO PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF 21



   It is unlawful for you to purchase alcoholic liquor or misrepresent
your age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic liquor.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.56  PROHIBITING PERSONS UNDER AGE OF 21 TO REMAIN ON LICENSED
PREMISES.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any holder of a retail liquor
dealer’s license or his agent or employee, to suffer or permit any person
under the age of 21 to be or remain in any room or compartment adjoining or
adjacent to or situated in the room or place where such licensed premises is
located; provided that this division shall not apply to any person under the
age of 21 who is accompanied by his parent or guardian or to any licensed
premises which derives its principal business from the sale of other
commodities or services than the sale of alcoholic liquor.



   (B)   No licensee, nor any officer, associate, member,
representative, agent or employee of such licensee who knows, or in the
exercise of reasonable care should know, that a person under the age of 21
years possesses or is consuming alcoholic liquor while on the premises shall
allow such minor to remain on such premises.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83; Am. Ord. 1177, passed 4-6-87; Am. Ord. 1254,
passed 3-6-89; Am. Ord. 1703, passed 6-1-98) 



Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.57  WRITTEN EVIDENCE OF AGE AND IDENTITY REQUIRED.



   (A)   For the purpose of preventing violation of this chapter, any
licensee or his agent or employee may refuse to sell or serve alcoholic
liquor to any person who is unable to produce adequate written evidence of
identity or of the fact that he is over the age of 21 years.



   (B)   Adequate written evidence of age and identity of the person is
a document issued by a federal, state, county or municipal government or
subdivision or agency thereof, including, but not limited to a motor vehicle
operators license, a registration certificate issued under the Federal
Selective Service Act or an identification card issued to a member of the
armed forces.  Proof that the defendant, licensee or his employees or agent
demanded, was shown and reasonably relied upon such written evidence in any
transaction forbidden by this chapter is competent evidence and may be
considered in any prosecution therefor or to any proceedings for the
suspension or revocation of any license based thereon.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)



§ 113.58  MISREPRESENTATION OF AGE.



   (A)   Any person who sells, gives or furnishes to any person under
the age of 21 years, any false or fraudulent written, printed or photostatic
evidence of the age and identity of such person or who sells, gives or
furnishes to any person under the age of 21 years, evidence of age and
identification or any other person is guilty of a violation of this chapter.



   (B)   Any person under the age of 21 years who presents or offers to
any licensee, his agent or employee written, printed or photostatic evidence
of age and identity which is false, fraudulent or not actually his own, for
the purpose of ordering, purchasing, attempting to purchase or otherwise
procuring or attempting to procure serving of any alcoholic liquor or who has
in his possession any false or fraudulent written, printed or photostatic
evidence of age and identity is guilty of a violation of this chapter.



   (C)   Any person under the age of 21 years, who has any alcoholic
liquor in his possession on any street or highway or in any public place open
to the public is guilty of a violation of this chapter.  This does not apply
to a person under the age of 21 years making a delivery of alcoholic liquor
in pursuance of the order of his parent or in pursuance of his employment.



   (D)   Whoever violates provisions of this section shall be guilty of
a violation of this chapter.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.59  PURCHASE OR POSSESSION OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR; EXCEPTION.



   (A)   Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of any alcoholic
liquor is prohibited because of age shall not purchase or accept a gift of
such alcoholic liquor or have such alcoholic liquor in his possession.  If a
licensee or his agents or employees believes or has reason to believe that
the sale or delivery of any alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of the
nonage of the prospective recipient, he shall before making such sale or
delivery demand presentation of some form of positive identification
containing proof of age.  No person shall transfer, alter or deface such an
identification card, use the identification card of another, carry or use a
false or forged identification  card or obtain an identification  by 
means of false  information.  No person  shall  purchase,  accept 
delivery or  have possession of alcoholic liquor in violation of this
section.  The consumption of alcoholic liquor by any person under the age of
21 years is forbidden.  Whoever violates provisions of this section shall be
guilty of a violation of this chapter.



   (B)   Possession and dispensing or consumption by a minor of
alcoholic liquor in a performance of a religious service or ceremony or the
consumption by a minor under the direct supervision and approval of the
parent or parents of such minor in the privacy of a home is not prohibited by
this section.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.60  TENDING BAR BY UNDERAGE PERSONS PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to attend
any bar, dispense, draw, pour, mix or sell any alcoholic liquor in any
licensed retail premises.  It shall be unlawful for any licensee, officer,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee to allow any
person under the age of 21 to attend any bar, dispense, draw, pour, mix or
sell any alcoholic liquor in the licensed retail premises.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83; Am. Ord. 1263, passed 6-19-89; Am. Ord. 2822,
passed 12-3-12)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.61  SALE, GIFT OR DELIVERY TO MINOR.



   (A)   No licensee nor any officer, associate, member,
representative, agent or employee of such licensee shall sell, give or
deliver alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of 21 years, or to any
intoxicated person or to any person known by him to be under legal disability
or in need of mental treatment.



   (B)   No person, after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic
liquor, shall sell, give or deliver such alcoholic liquor to another person
under the age of 21 years, except in the performance of a religious ceremony
or service.



   (C)   Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of any alcoholic
liquor is prohibited because of age shall not purchase, or accept a gift of
such alcoholic liquor or have such alcoholic liquor in his possession.



(Ord. 1177, passed 4-6-87; Am. Ord. 1254, passed 3-6-89)



§ 113.62  POSSESSION OR CONSUMPTION OF ALCOHOL BY A GATHERING INCLUDING
MINOR AT RESIDENCE.



   (A)   No person shall knowingly permit a gathering at a residence
which he occupies of two or more persons where any one or more persons is 
under 21 years of age and the following factors also apply:



      (1)   The person occupying the residence knows that any such
person under the age of 21 is in possession of or is consuming any alcoholic
beverage;



      (2)   The possession or consumption of the alcohol by the
person under 21 years of age is not otherwise permitted by this chapter; or



      (3)   The person occupying the residence knows that the person
under the age of 21 leaves the residence in an intoxicated condition.



   (B)   It is unlawful for a parent or guardian to permit his or her
residence to be used by an invitee of the parents’ child or the
guardian’s ward, if the invitee is under the age of 21, in a manner that
constitutes a violation of this chapter.  A parent or guardian is deemed to
have permitted his or her residence to be used in violation of this chapter
if he or she knowingly authorizes, enables or permits such use to occur by
failing to control access to either the residence or the alcoholic liquor
maintained in the residence.  (Ord. 1177, passed 4-6-87; Am. Ord. 1254,
passed 3-6-89; Am. Ord. 1703, passed 6-1-98)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.63  PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY.



   It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian to permit any child
under the age of 21 of which he is parent or guardian, to violate any
provision of this chapter.



(Ord. 1177, passed 4-6-87; Am. Ord. 1254, passed 3-6-89)  Penalty, see §
113.99



FALL FESTIVAL



§ 113.75  PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION.



   Any holder or owner of a Class A, Class B, Class C, Class D, Class E,
Class G or Class H liquor license may apply for a permit to erect a
balustrade abutting, adjoining or contiguous with the premises operated by
the licensee subject to the following terms of this subchapter.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)



§ 113.76  APPLICATION FEE.



   An application under this subchapter shall be prepared and submitted by
a licensee as defined in this chapter and accompanied by a fee to be set by
the Board of Trustees, which shall be refunded if the application is denied.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)



§ 113.77  APPROVAL OR DENIAL OF APPLICATION.



   Subject to all applicable provisions of this chapter, the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner shall review and approve or deny any application.  If
approved, a permit incorporating the terms of this subchapter will be issued
to the licensee.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)



§ 113.78  DURATION.



   The licensee shall only be permitted to occupy the area which a
permitted balustrade during the days the Village Fall Festival is being held
or for such shorter time as the Local Liquor Control Commissioner deems
necessary.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)



§ 113.79  BALUSTRADES; CONSTRUCTION AND REQUIREMENTS.



   (A)   The licensee, at its sole cost and expense, shall erect,
construct and maintain a balustrade or an area cordoned off from general
public use and access for the sole purpose of providing an area for the
public to consume alcoholic liquors during the Village Fall Festival.



   (B)   All balustrades shall meet all requirements for public safety,
including providing suitable ingress for Police Department, Fire Department
and other public safety personnel.



   (C)   A diagram of the area and its proposed construction and
location in relation to the licensed premises shall accompany the permit.



   (D)   If the balustrade is to be erected or constructed on a
sidewalk or other public way, the licensee shall not damage any public
property in constructing, erecting or maintaining the balustrade and shall
further provide the village with an endorsement for insurance insuring the
village for any and all liability which may be occasioned on the premises in
an amount not less than $500,000/$1,000,000 and also execute an agreement to
indemnify and hold the village harmless from all matters associated with the
use of the area enclosed by the balustrade.



   (E)   If the balustrade is proposed to be constructed on a sidewalk
or other public way, the area within the balustrade shall not exceed the
length of the sidewalk actually abutting the licensed premises times the
width of that sidewalk.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83; Am. Ord. 1703, passed 6-1-98)  Penalty, see §
113.99



§ 113.80  (RESERVED).



§ 113.81  OUTDOOR BEER GARDEN/CAFE CONSTRUCTION AND REQUIREMENTS.



   Any holder of a Class A, Class B, Class C, Class D, Class E or Class H
liquor license may apply to the Liquor Commissioner for a permit to serve
liquor in an outdoor beer garden/cafe adjoining or contiguous to the premises
operated by the licensee subject to the following conditions:



   (A)   The owner shall submit a site plan depicting the layout of the
outdoor beer garden/cafe, including ingress, egress and occupant load. 
Canopies, screening and/or tents shall meet the flame spread ratings required
by the code and shall be safely secured.  Permanent structures shall be
designed and constructed according to applicable village code.



   (B)   Screening, canopies and/or roof structures shall be maintained
in accordance with the 1996 BOCA National Property Maintenance Code.  By
October 31 of the permitting year, the owner shall remove all fixtures
“table, chairs etc.,” from the outdoor beer garden/cafe area and all
screening and/or canopies shall also be removed.



   (C)   All alcohol must be served by a waitress/waiter.



   (D)   No alcohol to be served before 11:30 a.m. or after 11:00 p.m.,
except Friday and Saturday when liquor may be served until 12:00 midnight.



   (E)   The outdoor beer garden/cafe must be closed by 11:00 p.m.,
except Friday and Saturday when closing shall be 12:00 midnight.  At 12:00
midnight, all tables and the cafe area must be cleaned by closing.



   (F)   Any Special Events using the outdoor beer garden/cafe or
alteration of business hours will require a Special Permit, which can be
obtained from the village, with concurrence from the Liquor Commissioner.



   (G)   An annual permit fee of $15 is required to operate an outdoor
beer garden/cafe.



   (H)   A Special Event fee of $15 per event is required for use of an
outdoor beer garden/cafe after 11:00 p.m. weekdays and 12:00 midnight Friday
and Saturday.  A Special Permit will also be required for any use of outdoor
cooking, (except regular weekend barbecues), group activities such as wedding
parties or any activity deemed by the village as not consistent with the
normal function of an outdoor cafe.



   (I)   No outdoor band or musical equipment is permitted without a
Special Event Permit.



   (J)   The beer garden is to be taken down no later than October 31
of the year in which the permit is issued.



   (K)   No permit for an outdoor beer garden/cafe shall be issued
until each proposed beer garden/cafe has been inspected and approved for use
by the village.



(Ord. 1703, passed 6-1-98; Am. Ord. 1900, passed 6-17-02)



ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT



§ 113.90  LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER.



   The Village President is hereby designated the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner and is charged with the administration of this chapter and the
Liquor Control Act, ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, § 1-2, as the same now exists or
may be hereafter amended, and of such other ordinances and resolutions
relating to alcoholic liquor as may be needed.  The Village President may
appoint persons to assist him in the exercise of the power and performances
of the duties provided for such Local Liquor Control Commissioner.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)



§ 113.91  RECORDS OF LICENSES TO BE KEPT.



   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall keep or cause to be kept a
complete record of all such licenses issued by him and shall furnish the
Village Clerk, the Village Treasurer and the Chief of Police each with a copy
thereof upon the issuance of any new license and shall notify each of the
said officers, in writing, upon the issuance of any new licenses or
revocation of any old licenses, within 24 hours of its issuance or revocation.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)



§ 113.92  RIGHT OF ENTRY FOR INSPECTION.



   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner is hereby given the power to
enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter at any time upon any
premises licensed hereunder to determine whether any of the provisions of
this chapter, “An act relating to alcoholic liquor,” ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5,
§§ 1-1 et seq., or any rules or regulations adopted by him or by the State
Liquor Commissioner have been or are being violated and at such time to
examine the premises of said licensee in connection therewith.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)



§ 113.93  HEARINGS BEFORE LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER.



   Any hearing before the Local Liquor Control Commissioner is transcribed
by a certified court or shorthand reporter.  Any appeal of the decision of
the Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall be based solely on the record
from said hearing and not a de novo review of the case.



(Ord. 1703, passed 6-1-98)



§ 113.98  VIOLATIONS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, partnership or
club to sell or offer for sale at retail within the village any alcoholic
liquor without having a retail liquor dealers license, or in violation of the
terms of such license or in violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the
provisions of this chapter shall, in addition to suspension or revocation of
license as provided in this chapter, be fined not more than $750 for each
offense.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during
and on which a violation occurs or continues.



(Ord. 1105, passed 12-5-83; Am. Ord. 1177, passed 4-6-87; Am. Ord. 1254,
passed 3-6-89; Am. Ord. 1943, passed 12-2-02)



   (B)   In addition to and not in lieu of any other remedies available
to the village under § 113.18(C), any person or entity found to have
violated any provision of § 113.18(C) shall be fined not less than $250 nor
more than $750, with each day of violation constituting a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2745, passed 10-3-11)



   (C)   In addition to and not in lieu of any other remedies available
to the village under § 113.18(E), any person or entity found to have
violated any provision of § 113.18(E) shall be fined not less than $250, not
more than $500, with each day of violation constituting a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2726, passed 6-20-11)



   (D)   In addition to and not in lieu of any other remedies available
to the village under § 113.20, any person or entity found to have violated
any provision of § 113.20 shall be fined not less than $250, not more than
$750, with each day of violation constituting a separate offense.  (Ord.
2800, passed 8-20-12; Am. Ord. 2932, passed 7-21-14)



   (E)   Any business or person found to have violated any provision of
§§ 113.20.1 or 113.21 shall be fined not less than $250 for the first
offense and not less than $500 for each subsequent offense.  (Ord. 2710,
passed 4-18-11)



CHAPTER 114:  PERSONAL PROPERTY SALES



Section



   114.01   Intent



   114.02   Permit required



   114.03   Application for permit



   114.04   Permit fee



   114.05   Conditions for issuance of permit



   114.06   Permit required for all sales at resident’s address



   114.07   Number of sales permitted



   114.08   Duration of permit



   114.09   Display of permit



   114.10   Sale of items to belong to occupant of premises



   114.11   Garage sale signs



   114.12   Right of inspection; arrest authority of inspector



 



   114.99   Penalty



§ 114.01  INTENT.



   It is the intent  of this chapter to regulate the term and frequency
of a personal property sale so as not to disturb or disrupt the residential
environment of the area.  It is not the intent of this chapter to seek
control of private sales by individuals selling a few of their household or
personal items which are sold at the residence.



(Ord. 1112, passed 3-19-84)



§ 114.02  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   Any person or organization desirous of holding a public auction or a
personal property sale, which includes but is not limited to garage,
basement, yard and porch sale, for the sale or resale of used household,
clothing or any other personal property items which are owned all or in part
by the occupants of the premises, shall  prior to such sale obtain a permit
from the village.



(Ord. 1112, passed 3-19-84)  Penalty, see § 114.99



§ 114.03  APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.



   A village resident shall apply for the permit with the Village Zoning
Enforcement Officer on forms furnished by the village.



(Ord. 1112, passed 3-19-84)



§ 114.04  PERMIT FEE.



   Each application for a permit shall be submitted with a permit fee to
be set by the Board of Trustees.  The application fee covers charges
associated with processing the application to determine if a permit should be
issued.



(Ord. 1112, passed 3-19-84)



§ 114.05  CONDITIONS FOR ISSUANCE OF PERMIT.



   (A)   The village will issue a sale permit only upon proper showing
and finding by the village that all safety and environmental precautions
necessary or convenient for such sale have been met.



   (B)   The applicant shall agree to abide by all conditions imposed
by the village as enumerated in this chapter.



(Ord. 1112, passed 3-19-84)



§ 114.06  PERMIT REQUIRED FOR ALL SALES AT RESIDENT’S ADDRESS.



   A permit is required for all sales.  Permits are issued to a resident
of the village, which permits the sale at the resident’s address.



(Ord. 1112, passed 3-19-84)



§ 114.07  NUMBER OF SALES PERMITTED.



   No sale shall be conducted nor will a sale permit be issued within 90
days from the last permitted sale date on the premises.



(Ord. 1112, passed 3-19-84)  Penalty, see § 114.99



§ 114.08  DURATION OF PERMIT.



   Permits are valid for any two consecutive days between the hours of
8:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m.  No permits will be issued allowing sales during the
Labor Day - Village Fall Festival weekend.



(Ord. 1112, passed 3-19-84)



§ 114.09  DISPLAY OF PERMIT.



   Permits shall be conspicuously displayed on the sale premises so as to
be seen by the public and village officials and employees.  (Ord. 1112,
passed 3-19-84)  Penalty, see § 114.99



§ 114.10  SALE OF ITEMS TO BELONG TO OCCUPANT OF PREMISES.



   The items to be sold must, for the most part, be owned by the occupant
of the sale premises.  However, the sale may include property owned by other
participating village residents.



(Ord. 1112, passed 3-19-84)



§ 114.11  GARAGE SALE SIGNS.



   (A)   Upon issuance of the sale permit the village will furnish the
applicant three garage sale signs.  No other signs may be displayed within
the corporate limits of the village.



   (B)   Garage sale signs shall not be displayed more than one day
prior to the commencement of the sale and must be removed no later than one
day following the conclusion of the permitted sale.



   (C)   One of the signs shall be displayed at the front lot line on
the premises on which the sale is conducted.



   (D)   No signs shall be placed on village property at the
intersections of U.S. Route 45 and Route 30, U.S. Route 45 and White Street,
or White Street and Nebraska Street.  No signs shall be placed in the
village flower beds. 



(Ord. 1112, passed 3-19-84)  Penalty, see § 114.99



§ 114.12  RIGHT OF INSPECTION; ARREST AUTHORITY OF INSPECTOR.



   A police officer or any official designated by any village ordinance to
make inspections under the licensing or regulating ordinance or to enforce
the same, shall have the right of entry to any premises showing evidence of a
personal property sale for the purpose of enforcement or inspection and may
close the premises from such a sale or arrest any person who violates any
provision of this chapter.



(Ord. 1112, passed 3-19-84)



§ 114.99  PENALTY.



   Any individual, partnership, firm, corporation or organization
violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, in addition to
revocation of license as above provided, be fined not less than $25 nor more
than $750 for each offense.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed on
each day during and on which a violation occurs or continues.



(Ord. 1112, passed 3-19-84; Am. Ord. 1943, passed 12-2-02)



CHAPTER 115: SOLICITORS, HAWKERS, AND PEDDLERS; CHARITABLE SOLICITATION



Section

   115.02   License required
